results.title: TwentyFourSeven = 24 7
results.creator_credit: Shane Meadows, Imogen West, Scala, BBC Film Unit and October Films
results.brief_description: TwentyFourSeven marks the screen debut of writer/director Shane Meadows with an assuredness and humour about working/under class people that is also to be a theme in subsequent films (“A Room for Romeo Brass”). Shot in black and white, the lack of colour adds to the washed-out public housing development in which unemployed families pass the time, time that does nothing to change their situations. Darcy (Bob Hoskins) fondly remembers in his youth that a boxing club gave him some hope, so he sets about combining the local gangs to form a youth club. Moments of humour in the script provide lighter distractions as the weight of the whole film and its import in post-Thatcher’s Britain can sit heavily with viewer. Among the failures and hopelessness, camaraderie and self-respect are not all lost along with demise of the club and Darcy’s descent into alcoholism. Great soundtrack, with a cast that includes: Frank Harper, Karl Collins, Bruce Jones and Danny Nussbaum. Co-written by Paul Fraser.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Shane Meadows, Imogen West, Scala, BBC Film Unit and October Films

results.title: Twenty-four hours in Czechoslovakia
results.creator_credit: David Bairstow, Walford Hewitson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Hockey star Stan Mikita of the Chicago Black Hawks visits his native Czechoslovakia for a family reunion. During the course of a day and an evening the film accompanies him, his Chicago-born wife, and their daughter to places familiar to him in Prague and in the little village of Sokolce where he was born. There are many glimpses of the life of the Czech people at work, at home and at leisure. Their enthusiasm for hockey is evident throughout the film, especially when Mikita works out with a Czech team.

results.title: Twentieth Century Masters
results.creator_credit: Terence Meast, Peter Isaac and Australian National Gallery
results.brief_description: The Twentieth Century Masters video features a selection from the 71 works exhibited in the Twentieth Century Masters exhibition at the Australian National Gallery, Canberra and the Queensland Art Gallery, in 1986. Shot at the Australian National Gallery this video includes a number of works in the gallery’s permanent collection by artists represented in the exhibition. School of Paris artists discussed on the video tape include: Picasso, Matisse, Bonnard, Derain, Chagall, Soutine and Modigliani. Other European artists considered are Paul Klee and Max Beckmann.

results.title: Twelve tuff tales
results.brief_description:
Twelve students from Grade 6 at Carlton Primary School create their own individual story about a “bad day” from their own perspective. Some examples of the stories include getting chased by snarling dogs in the park, falling over and ruining a new pair of jeans, losing a kid sister at the shops and getting lost in Safeways.
The children involved in making this collection of one-minute works were mostly refugee children who live on an inner Melbourne housing estate and speak English as a second language.
“Twelve tuff tales” was created as a school-based multimedia production and funded by an Arts and Culture grant from the City of Melbourne. It was produced at Artplay: the centre for contemporary arts for children.
The stories include:
1. Bandaids by Abir Musa
2. The Horrible day by Dunya Ahmen
3. Bullies at the park by Hashem Alhassan
4. Lost by Hodan Yusuf
5. Feeding the fishes by JD Bautista
6. Blown away by Meriam Abubeker
7. Untitled - no credits
8. Two big dogs with sharp teeth by Mustafa Housain
9. Untitled - no credits
10. The Shower by Sadam Ahmed
11. Grounded by Thao Le
12. Lost in High Point by Shukri Ismail

results.title: Twelve o'clock high
results.creator_credit: Henry King, Darryl F. Zanuck and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Featuring authentic aerial battle film, this gritty World War 2 action film emphasises the heroic but perilious face of war. Convinced that an air force commander is at breaking point, Brigadier General Savage takes over the struggling bomber troop. He uses strict disciplinary tactics, despite his kind and understanding nature, to revitalise a demoralised troop. At first resentful and rebellious, the flyers learn to gradually respect Savage and to perform as expected. Eventually the stress of command begins to take its toll on Savage, until he too faces breaking point. Starring Gregory Peck, Dean Jagger, Hugh Marlowe, Gary Merrill and Millard Mitchell.

results.title: What's for dinner?
results.brief_description: This 3D animation tells the story of Angus and his overbearing mother Beryl. Eventually Angus must decide whether he wants to rid himself of Beryl forever…to be continued, Completed as part of a visual arts degree in graphic design

results.title: What's eating Gilbert Grape?
results.creator_credit: Lasse Hallstrom, David Matalon, Bertil Ohlsson, Meir Teper, J and M Entertainment and Matalon Teper Ohlsson Production
results.brief_description: From the acclaimed director of “My life as a dog”, “What’s eating Gilbert Grape?” is a moving and at times comic portrayal of an unusual family in a small town. Gilbert (Johnny Depp) must keep a vigilant eye on his family, particularly his intellectually disabled younger brother Arnie (Leonardo Di Caprio) and his reclusive mother. When a stranger (Juliette Lewis) comes to town, she not only captures his heart, but also turns his life around.

results.title: Whale rider. Cracker bag
results.creator_credit: Glendyn Ivin, Niki Caro, Jane Liscombe, Frank Hubner, John Barnett, Tim Sanders, Exit Films, Ruby Films, Outerspace, Pandora Films, Apollo Media and South Pacific Pictures
results.brief_description: Whale Rider: Set in a small village in rural New Zealand, “Whale Rider” is the story of a Maori community who are looking for a new male heir as leader. All looks certain until the heir apparent and his mother die at childbirth leaving his twin, Pai, a baby girl. Pai (Keisha Castle-Hughes) has to overcome 1000 years of tradition and the fierce determination of her beloved grandfather to assert her rightful place as leader and re-unite her people. Beautiful landscapes, moody music and underwater photography add to the lush look of this film. Internationally acclaimed and multi-award winning feature film. Based on the novel “The Whale Rider” by Witi Ihmaera. “Cracker bag”: Personal childhood memories are evoked when watching this Australian short about a young girl, Eddie, as she saves her money to buy fireworks for Guy Fawkes Night. Set in the 1980s, “Cracker Bag” is a tender suburban study that finely depicts a disheartening pivotal moment in the life of a young girl. Photographic-like in its 35mm presentation, “Cracker bag” is deservedly Winner of the Palme D’Or (Short Film) Festival De Cannes 2003 and many other accolades. Written and directed by Glendyn Ivin, starring young Edith Cattell as Eddie.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Glendyn Ivin, Niki Caro, Jane Liscombe, Frank Hubner, John Barnett, Tim Sanders, Exit Films, Ruby Films, Outerspace, Pandora Films, Apollo Media and South Pacific Pictures

results.title: Whale hunting
results.creator_credit: Mosha Michael, Peter Raymont and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An interesting and informative journey with six Inuit hunters in their hunt of the Beluga whale near Frobisher Bay, N.W.T. We learn about the methods used in pursuing the whale and dividing the carcass.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mosha Michael, Peter Raymont and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Tom Olsson's Cohuna
results.brief_description: Cohuna - When Cohuna Higher Elementary School wanted to raise money for a film projector in 1952, local resident Tom Olsson decided to help by filming life in the township and surrounding countryside, and then showing the footage in the local Town Hall. His footage has been lovingly compiled by the Cohuna Historical Society and the resulting film give us a special glimpse into rural life in 1950’s Victoria. The school recieved their projector, and Olsson’s films were shown annually as a Christmas treat for many years afterward.
